**AW RITE! AW RITE! AW RITE!**

LET'S GOOOO! TIME TO ***KICK IT UP A NOTCH!***

Excited for Brian Broussard and his brother/business partner John Broussard.  They are taking their practice, *PRIDE Strength Training* to new heights and a new location in Tampa! LET'S GOOO! 

Christina Marie Ramirez shared her KNAHLEDGE by teaching CCISD (Houston area) coaches and phys ed teachers about stretching!! LOVE IT!!

Luis Alfonso is passing along his passion for fitness to his son.  In four weeks, his son went from unable to jog twice around the track to running two miles PLUS a 45 min non-stop conditioning workout program!! WAY TO GO, LITTLE MAN!!!

F Scott Feil continues to add to his incredibleness.  He has now published a children's book! Available on Amazon!

Katie Balgeman told the world that mini bagel #3 is due possibly late December!! CONGRATS!!!

Ginger Morrissey and her practice, *Pin Point Physical Therapy, LLC,* is growing so much that she is moving into a new location!! SUHWEET!!!

Tameka Johnson has announced that after 7 incredible years, Vitality Sport and Rehab will be closing its doors in Clarksville, TN.  Never fear. It's for a new and exciting chapter in her personal and professional life!  We look forward to learning about her journey! Many blessings, Tameka!!!

YOU, all the members of this UNCAGED community, are changing  lives!  KEEP GOING!!!

post_text:
Taking the leap into entrepreneurship comes with all sorts of doubts, fears, and anxieties.

The first order of business (no pun intended) for all new practice owners is to grow a caseload that allows them to replace their salaries so as to not jeopardize their financial well being.

Totally understandable.

In order to grow a thriving business - one that ensures lasting success - the entrepreneur must begin to make the transition from "busy self-employed clinician" to a business leader; regardless of whether the plans are to add staff, locations, or not.

Becoming a leader, no matter the size of the company, takes some know-how.

One of the top skills any leader should learn is how to become skilled at Decision Making.

For all of us, the quality of our decisions will help to shape the quality of our lives, and our businesses.

The challenge happens to be that most of us are not great at making decisions, even down to the little day-to-day things.

post_text: Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

comments.text: My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value as well

full_thread_text:
POST: Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

COMMENT 1: My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

COMMENT 2: At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value as well

post_text:
Hello, I am considering buying out the outpatient practice I work in. I have a general idea of business valuation (~1.2x the average revenue over several years).  However, I've been told that since this is a service-based industry, it has less value when sold? 

For the clinicians who own a private outpatient practice, can you shed some insight on where to start or what resources to utilize to get a good understanding? I don't want to sound uncertain or confused once I start discussing this with my boss.  Thank you for your time!

comments.text: 100% get an attorney and have someone do due diligence on their finances before any offers are in the table
Don't do this without attorneys for contracts and accountant to make a proper valuation.  Can cost more upfront but can save you huge amounts of money down the road.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello, I am considering buying out the outpatient practice I work in. I have a general idea of business valuation (~1.2x the average revenue over several years).  However, I've been told that since this is a service-based industry, it has less value when sold? 

For the clinicians who own a private outpatient practice, can you shed some insight on where to start or what resources to utilize to get a good understanding? I don't want to sound uncertain or confused once I start discussing this with my boss.  Thank you for your time!

COMMENT 1: 100% get an attorney and have someone do due diligence on their finances before any offers are in the table

COMMENT 2: Don't do this without attorneys for contracts and accountant to make a proper valuation.  Can cost more upfront but can save you huge amounts of money down the road.

post_text: What is the best way to go about selling your business? There is a good chance that my husband is getting relocated and I'm trying to figure out what to do next. I'd really hate to just have to scrap everything I've worked for and pass my patients off to a different clinic.

comments.text: Tough, sole practitioner are tough to sell, cuz your patients like you. Start immediately, call every therapist you know and sell them on the idea of being there own boss and the financial benefits. Be honest and open. Make it a win -win. Someone wants to be in your shoes, GL

Is there any chance you can hire a PT and continue to operate the business from another state? You would do all the admin work and the therapist would see the patients. You would likely earn more from operating the business like this for a couple years instead of selling

post_text:
"I lost 10 pounds in a week! Looking to lose weight before the holidays? Message me "fit for the holidays" and I'll give you information."

True store.  I really have lost 10 pounds over the last week stuck in bed with the flu.

Does this type of hook (attractive statement) sound familiar? We've all seen it. I've done something remarkable and want to share with others how they too can have the unprecedented success they've had. 

Does it seem too good to be true? 

Does it make sense to lose 10# in a week? Is that healthy? 

We want your business to grow and we want you to do it in as healthy a way as possible.

Fast growth can happen. We've had seasons of ridiculous growth in the past and some has been healthy but a lot of our fast growth hasn't been that healthy. 

It's not sexy to tell people to grow in a healthy way but that's what we're going to continue shouting from the rooftops.

comments.text:
Sustainable growth and laying a rock solid foundation are key! 

Keep teaching the right methods, your reputation and client outcomes will (and do) speak on your behalf. ðŸ‘ðŸ¼
Hope you are feeling better

post_text:
Need some advice/words of wisdom

I moved from a full time SNF + side hustle to 3 day part time at the SNF and 2 day part time working for my cash only practice at the beginning of November. I structure it typically for 60-75 min treatments and 90 minute evals and have been ramping up to 3-4 visits a week. So right now I am still pretty dependent on the income for those visits to replace the days not at the SNF (6 visits/wk is break even with expenses) I  heavily use counterstrain as a manual technique and that is generally what brings in the clients. The colleague/mentor who introduced me to this technique and had a part time cash practice recently told me they were moving out of state and said she would recommend her clients to see me when they needed therapy. Then, she also connected with a retired PT in the area who reached out who owned several insurance base clinics in the past and extensively studied counterstrain and was certified in it. At our first meeting, he mentioned that he isnâ€™t getting satisfaction doing PRN 1-2 days a week for SNFs and doesnâ€™t want all his knowledge with counterstrain to go to waste with him retiring. He told me his goal was to help my business grow and be able to pass on his knowledge. He mentioned money wasnâ€™t important since he was retired and if I wanted to utilize him, then pay him what I felt he is worth. Of course with his business knowledge and clinical knowledge, my first thought was there was no way I can afford what he is worth. I know Iâ€™ve had a lot of these doors just open in front of me and I want to take advantage of these opportunities but looking for some wisdom on how to utilize him to grow personally and grow the business to hopefully full time but also make a wise financial decision too. Iâ€™m meeting with him a second time soon but Iâ€™ve been racking my brain on how to utilize him not just as a 2nd therapist to generate income but more as a mentor and how that would play out as well as how to pay him.

comments.text: I would have an honest conversation about what he wants you to pay him. Give him your honest situation and then ask him to tell you what he would do in his situation. Use that to make a decision on pay. I would highly recommend you co treat with him so you get better at counterstrain (it's mainly what I do). Mentorship with FCS is essential

Agree with David Harvitz you need to get a firm number in place before he starts providing services on your behalf. Sounds like a chill dude and doesnâ€™t want to put stress on you, but trust me it will be more stressful trying to figure out what he is worth later as he either provides a lot of financial value, or doesnâ€™t.

Iâ€™m meeting with him a second time soon but Iâ€™ve been racking my brain on how to utilize him not just as a 2nd therapist to generate income but more as a mentor and how that would play out as well as how to pay him.

COMMENT 1: I would have an honest conversation about what he wants you to pay him. Give him your honest situation and then ask him to tell you what he would do in his situation. Use that to make a decision on pay. I would highly recommend you co treat with him so you get better at counterstrain (it's mainly what I do). Mentorship with FCS is essential

COMMENT 2: Agree with David Harvitz you need to get a firm number in place before he starts providing services on your behalf. Sounds like a chill dude and doesnâ€™t want to put stress on you, but trust me it will be more stressful trying to figure out what he is worth later as he either provides a lot of financial value, or doesnâ€™t.

Do you build your business with legacy in mind?
IE: what happens to the business after I'm gone? Who will take over the reins? Can it go on without me?
OR
Do you build your business with an exit strategy?
IE: build it to a certain point then sell it?
OR
Do you just build it to serve you now and enjoy the ride?
If this one....what might the complications of closing the business look like that could be prepared for now?

post_text: I figured this group could be a great resource. What is the market pulse in private practice business Valuation in 2023? I think the industry standard is adjusted EBITDA multiple of 3-5X. Are most calculating EBITDA off trailing 12 months, past year, or average of past years. Anyone will to chat or who might have any insight in this area would be much appreciated.

comments.text:
Unfortunately there is no exact science for business valuation and depends on so many factors such as years in business, location, local and outside competition etc. 
Normally it is last 3 years weighted SDE or EBITDA. I have seen therapy practices sell for 2 to 3 multiples. Occasionally 4, IF the seller sees exponential growth in the future. Hope this helps.
that multiplle is high for my area.  closer to 1x AR.

ðŸ—£ï¸A MESSAGEâ€¼ï¸

A violinist played for 45 minutes in the New York subway.  A handful of people stopped, a couple clapped, and the violinist raised about $30 in tips. 

No one knew this, but the violinist was Joshua Bell, one of the best musicians in the world. In that subway, Joshua played one of the most intricate pieces ever written with a violin worth 3.5 million dollars.

Two days before he played in the subway, Joshua Bell sold out a Boston theatre, and the seats averaged about $100. 

The experiment proved that the extraordinary in an ordinary environment does not shine and is so often overlooked and undervalued.

There are brilliantly talented people everywhere who arenâ€™t receiving the recognition and reward they deserve. But once they arm themselves with value and confidence and remove themselves from an environment that isnâ€™t serving them, they thrive and grow. 

Your gut is telling you something. Listen to it if itâ€™s telling you where you are isnâ€™t enough! 

Go where you are appreciated and valued. 

Know Your Worth.

@shaynevibes_truth

post_text: Is it worth it to purchase the domain you want in .com (for $2500) if .org is currently available?

comments.text: Buy them all. If youâ€™ve done a good job with a business name, owning all digital real estate is important.

Agree with others. If you can tweak it a little to get the .com Iâ€™d go that route but if not choosing another works too. The typical understanding of .org for organizations and things like that is shifting since we are running out of urls. But also depends a little on your clientele in my opinion. If you are targeting an older population, stick with .com for sure. Younger population more understanding of difference url endings.

The typical understanding of .org for organizations and things like that is shifting since we are running out of urls. But also depends a little on your clientele in my opinion. If you are targeting an older population, stick with .com for sure. Younger population more understanding of difference url endings.
